items.content_html: Finished watching: Oppenheimer. Superb acting from a cast I didn‚Äôt expect tells a story I of which only knew a small fraction. Fun sound design, although parts were noisier than they needed to be. Only real complaint is that it did not need all 180 minutes, and some bits dragged unnecessarily. üçø
items.content_text: Finished watching: [Oppenheimer](https://www.themoviedb.org/movie/872585-oppenheimer). Superb acting from a cast I didn‚Äôt expect tells a story I of which only knew a small fraction. Fun sound design, although parts were noisier than they needed to be. Only real complaint is that it did not need all 180 minutes, and some bits dragged unnecessarily. üçø

items.content_html:
Finished reading: The One Hour Bible by SPCK. Edited by Philip Law. A great idea‚Äînot paraphrasing or summarizing but eliding: using the actual words of the New Living Translation to tell the story of God in fewer words.

Unfortunately, while this treatment works well for the Old Testament and most of the Gospels, they abridge Acts too much, and the rest of the New Testament disappears until Revelation 22. I know it doesn‚Äôt fit the format, but ironically one of the elided verses (2 Timothy 3:16) says, ‚Äúall Scripture is useful.‚Äù üìö
items.content_text:
Finished reading: [The One Hour Bible](https://micro.blog/books/9780281079650) by SPCK. Edited by Philip Law. A great idea‚Äînot paraphrasing or summarizing but eliding: using the actual words of the New Living Translation to tell the story of God in fewer words.

<!--more-->

Unfortunately, while this treatment works well for the Old Testament and most of the Gospels, they abridge Acts too much, and the rest of the New Testament disappears until Revelation 22. I know it doesn‚Äôt fit the format, but ironically one of the elided verses (2 Timothy 3:16) says, ‚Äú*all* Scripture is useful.‚Äù üìö

items.title: Non-Alcoholic Beer Replacements We've Tried, With Notes
items.content_html:
We have tried a bunch of non-alcoholic (n/a) beers lately, looking for something that satisfies the desire for something bubbly and refreshing but doesn’t have the associated buzz, drowsiness, lack of focus, terrible sleep, and other downsides of the high-ABV beverages we’ve come to enjoy.

This is an unordered list of the ones we’ve tried with comments where applicable. All drinks with the same name as alcoholic beers are the non-alcoholic versions.

  • Athletic - has a ton of different flavors, most of them very expensive (>$2/drink on their website); we’ve only tried the beers, not the seltzers
    • Upside Dawn - a golden ale that has nothing to do with golden ale, but is tasty nonetheless; my wife’s favorite n/a beer
    • Cerveza Atletica - my wife’s second-favorite n/a beer
  • Brooklyn Brewery Special Effects
    • Hoppy Amber - not on the top of my list for n/a beers, but comes in the variety pack, so what are you going to do?
    • IPA - a little bit thicker than a real IPA would be, but without the bite of alcohol to balance it out
    • Pils - I don’t love alcoholic pils, so I’m not to be trusted, but it’s just as crisp and satisfying after a day in the woods (or the yard)
    • Hazy IPA - delicious; as far as I’m concerned, nearly a complete beer substitute‚Äîas long as you only like one flavor of IPA, because this is the only one I’ve found that’s this good
  • Deschutes Black Butte Porter - different from the real thing, but delicious.
  • Sierra Nevada Hop Splash “hop water” - a weird beverage that reminds you of beer but clearly isn’t trying to actually be beer; recommended despite my use of the word “weird”

Drinks that have been suggested to us, but which we haven’t tried yet

  • Independence Brewing KAW! Sparkling Hop Water
  • Asahi Super Dry 0.0 - recommended by @TheMacPsych
  • Erdinger Non-Alcoholic - also recommended by @TheMacPsych
  • Guinness 0.0 - recommended by many people
  • Heineken 0.0 - recommended by seemingly every ad on every Formula¬†1 track for the last few years
  • crux fermentation project - recommended by @jean, specifically the No-Mo Hazy

We still love great beers and ciders, and I’m sure you’ll see us at The Dooryard this weekend, but this kind of variety is a wonderful change from the previous alcohol-or-nothing regime.
items.content_text:
We have tried a bunch of non-alcoholic (n/a) beers lately, looking for something that satisfies the desire for something bubbly and refreshing but doesn't have the associated buzz, drowsiness, lack of focus, terrible sleep, and other downsides of the high-ABV beverages we've come to enjoy.

This is an unordered list of the ones we've tried with comments where applicable. All drinks with the same name as alcoholic beers are the non-alcoholic versions.

* [Athletic](https://athleticbrewing.com) - has a ton of different flavors, most of them very expensive (>$2/drink on their website); we've only tried the beers, not the seltzers
    * Upside Dawn - a golden ale that has nothing to do with golden ale, but is tasty nonetheless; my wife's favorite n/a beer
    * Cerveza Atletica - my wife's second-favorite n/a beer
* Brooklyn Brewery [Special Effects](https://brooklynbrewery.com/brooklyn-beers/non-alcoholic/special-effects-variety-pack/)
    * Hoppy Amber - not on the top of my list for n/a beers, but comes in the variety pack, so what are you going to do?
    * IPA - a little bit thicker than a real IPA would be, but without the bite of alcohol to balance it out
    * Pils - I don't love alcoholic pils, so I'm not to be trusted, but it's just as crisp and satisfying after a day in the woods (or the yard)
    * Hazy IPA - delicious; as far as I'm concerned, nearly a complete beer substitute‚Äîas long as you only like one flavor of IPA, because this is the only one I've found that's this good
* Deschutes [Black Butte Porter](https://www.deschutesbrewery.com/beer/na-black-butte-/) - different from the real thing, but delicious.
* Sierra Nevada [Hop Splash](https://sierranevada.com/brews/hop-splash/) "hop water" - a weird beverage that reminds you of beer but clearly isn't trying to actually be beer; recommended despite my use of the word "weird"

## Drinks that have been suggested to us, but which we haven't tried yet

* Independence Brewing [KAW! Sparkling Hop Water](https://checkout.independencebrewing.com/products/kaw-hop-water-6-pack)
* [Asahi Super Dry 0.0](https://www.asahiinternational.com/stories/innovation/asahi-00-launch/) - [recommended](https://www.macpsy.ch/2023/07/18/relaxing-with-an.html) by [@TheMacPsych](https://www.macpsy.ch)
* [Erdinger Non-Alcoholic](https://us.erdinger.de/beer/non-alcoholic.html) - also [recommended](https://micro.blog/TheMacPsych/21076988) by [@TheMacPsych](https://micro.blog/TheMacPsych)
* [Guinness 0.0](https://www.guinness.com/en/beers/guinness-zero) - recommended by [many](https://micro.blog/BenSouthwood/21078237) [people](https://micro.blog/TheMacPsych/21076988)
* [Heineken 0.0](https://www.heineken.com/us/en/our-beers/heineken-0-0) - recommended by seemingly every ad on every Formula¬†1 track for the last few years
* [crux fermentation project](https://www.cruxfermentation.com/beer/) - recommended by [@jean](https://micro.blog/jean), specifically the No-Mo Hazy

We still love great beers and ciders, and I'm sure you'll see us at [The Dooryard](https://thedooryardsa.com) this weekend, but this kind of variety is a wonderful change from the previous alcohol-or-nothing regime.

items.content_html:
Finished reading: For the Body by Timothy C. Tennent. A critical exposition of the need for the modern church to develop and espouse a positive theology of the body rather than the decades of pure negative theology: ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do that; that‚Äôs wrong.‚Äù

A great starter book on the topic, although the last two chapters are aimed squarely at pastors, not laypeople (they still have value, but not as much).

My primary takeaway is that developing a positive, holistic theology of the body allows us to see our sexuality, our bodies, and ourselves in the context of the complete gospel, not by the light of a few specific verses that mostly just make people angry regardless of what they believe. üìö

My primary takeaway is that developing a positive, holistic theology of the body allows us to see our sexuality, our bodies, and ourselves in the context of the complete gospel, not by the light of a few specific verses that mostly just make people angry regardless of what they believe. üìö

items.content_html: Finished watching: Silo (2023). Incredibly slow start, but every episode was better than the last, and the final scene is worth all ten episodes. I’m not sure if it was better that I’d read the books first, or worse because I didn’t have any suspense. üçø

items.content_html:
I had forgotten how much getting a car serviced costs. My 2014 Altima has been solid since I got it in 2016, modulo oil changes and tire changes, but today it needed some (expensive) help.

It was a lot of time and a lot of money, but I guess I can‚Äôt complain about one expensive trip in seven years.

items.content_html:
Finished reading: Senlin Ascends by Josiah Bancroft. Tremendously dissatisfying. A chaotic run through a fascinating world, but the plot was so contrived to prevent progress as to frustrate me with every page turn.

Not recommended. If you want a weird world, go read Piranesi instead. üìö
items.content_text:
Finished reading: [Senlin Ascends](https://micro.blog/books/9780316517904) by Josiah Bancroft. Tremendously dissatisfying. A chaotic run through a fascinating world, but the plot was so contrived to prevent progress as to frustrate me with every page turn.

Not recommended. If you want a weird world, go read *Piranesi* instead. üìö

items.title: My First iOS Apps
items.content_html:
Today, Phil Schiller celebrated the 15th anniversary of the iOS App Store, and many people posted the first apps they downloaded. Here are mine.

  • AIM
  • Google Earth
  • Mocha VNC Lite
  • BJCP Styles1
  • Holy Bible 2
  • Cocktails - The Original3
  • Mantis Bible Study4
  • Bible (YouVersion)5

  1. Beer Judge Certification Program, all about different styles of beers and how to evaluate them. Inspired by my undergrad courses in fermented beverages. ↩︎

  2. I don’t even remember this Bible app. I’ve used the YouVersion app almost every day since October 27, 2008. ↩︎

  3. I’m sensing a theme. ↩︎

  4. I’m sensing another theme. ↩︎

  5. I have used this app more than any other, with the possible exception of Apple’s Messages app. ↩︎
items.content_text: Today, [Phil Schiller celebrated the 15th anniversary of the iOS App Store](https://mstdn.social/@pschiller/110690395011183022), and many people posted the first apps they downloaded. Here are mine. * AIM * Google Earth * Mocha VNC Lite * BJCP Styles[^beer] * Holy Bible [^bible] * Cocktails - The Original[^cocktails] * Mantis Bible Study[^mantis] * Bible (YouVersion)[^youversion] [^beer]: Beer Judge Certification Program, all about different styles of beers and how to evaluate them. Inspired by my undergrad courses in fermented beverages. [^bible]: I don't even remember this Bible app. I've used the YouVersion app almost every day since October 27, 2008. [^cocktails]: I'm sensing a theme. [^mantis]: I'm sensing another theme. [^youversion]: I have used this app more than any other, with the possible exception of Apple's Messages app.

items.title: Pharrell Williams's "Happy" as a Spenserian Sonnet
items.content_html:
Back in 2014, there was a Twitter account, or maybe a Tumblr account, that published pop songs as sonnets1. I loved the spin on genre, but I noticed that they were all Petrarchan (Italian) sonnets, which go ABBA ABBA CDE CDE, or Shakespearean (English) sonnets, which go ABAB CDCD EFEF GG.

I complained on Twitter that we needed Spenserian ones, which have a harder rhyme scheme: ABAB BCBC CDCD EE. But you shouldn’t complain without offering a solution, so I give you my offering:

Tho' oft my speech ere uttering seem mad,
Fair Helios signals end of labor’s reign
O’er you and I, who, lightened, upward gad—
Ascend beyond the heav’ns' celestial plane
Lo, trumpets sound our doom, and promise pain:
Your harbinger I welcome, arms ope’d wide
For I, cloth√®d in joy, will be not slain
Let not your countenance be hurt, nor pride
Know I, and I alone, yield to no tide
No force of earth, nor beast, nor god could quell
The rise and rise unstoppable inside
Of happiness whose bounds no man can tell
—Now strike! your hands together, join the din
A roofless room, a bonafide boon, within.

  1. Apparently they published the collection in a book. ↩︎
items.content_text:
Back in 2014, there was a Twitter account, or maybe a Tumblr account, that published pop songs as sonnets[^1]. I loved the spin on genre, but I noticed that they were all Petrarchan (Italian) sonnets, which go ABBA ABBA CDE CDE, or Shakespearean (English) sonnets, which go ABAB CDCD EFEF GG.

I complained on Twitter that we needed Spenserian ones, which have a harder rhyme scheme: ABAB BCBC CDCD EE. But you shouldn't complain without offering a solution, so I give you my offering:

> Tho' oft my speech ere uttering seem mad,  
> Fair Helios signals end of labor's reign  
> O'er you and I, who, lightened, upward gad---  
> Ascend beyond the heav'ns' celestial plane  
> Lo, trumpets sound our doom, and promise pain:  
> Your harbinger I welcome, arms ope'd wide  
> For I, cloth√®d in joy, will be not slain  
> Let not your countenance be hurt, nor pride  
> Know I, and I alone, yield to no tide  
> No force of earth, nor beast, nor god could quell  
> The rise and rise unstoppable inside  
> Of happiness whose bounds no man can tell  
> ---Now strike! your hands together, join the din  
> A roofless room, a bonafide boon, within.

[^1]: Apparently they published the collection in [a book](https://micro.blog/books/9780008137199).

items.title: I Made a Swift Game
items.content_html:
I’ve been obsessed with Demonin’s Array Game since Andy Baio linked to it a month ago.

After getting effectively to the current endgame (there’s no real end, but at some point there’s no “next upgrade”), it occurred to me that the simplicity of the game was ideal for me to try learning Swift again.

I dove all the way into Swift and SwiftUI, first using Swift Playgrounds and then Xcode directly. It’s amazing how quickly a simple app can come together using all these tools and the crazy-fast REPL that is Playgrounds.

Here’s a video of the first level as of today.
items.content_text:
I've been obsessed with Demonin's [Array Game](https://demonin.com/games/arrayGame/) since Andy Baio [linked to it](https://waxy.org/2023/06/array-game/) a month ago.

After getting effectively to the current endgame (there's no real end, but at some point there's no "next upgrade"), it occurred to me that the simplicity of the game was ideal for me to try learning Swift again.

I dove all the way into Swift and SwiftUI, first using [Swift Playgrounds](https://www.apple.com/swift/playgrounds/) and then Xcode directly. It's amazing how quickly a simple app can come together using all these tools and the crazy-fast [REPL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Read‚Äìeval‚Äìprint_loop) that is Playgrounds.

Here's a video of the first level as of today.

<video controls="controls" playsinline="playsinline" src="https://micro.jerrytowler.com/uploads/2023/video.mov" width="640" height="1388" poster="https://micro.jerrytowler.com/uploads/2023/82f6aae94b.png" preload="none"></video>

items.content_html:
I just accidentally used the Universal Control feature built into macOS Ventura. I had set up my work MacBook Pro next to the monitor for my personal Mac mini, where I used to keep my laptop when it was connected to this monitor. So I naturally just hauled the cursor beyond the side of the screen, and it magically kept going onto the laptop screen!

It took me several seconds to figure out that something special had happened and that my cursor had jumped from one machine to the other.

Something weird: how did it know which side of my monitor the laptop was on? It could guess by choosing the direction you try to move your cursor, exactly like I did, but it’s still absolutely delightful.
items.content_text: I just accidentally used the [Universal Control](https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212757) feature built into macOS Ventura. I had set up my work MacBook Pro next to the monitor for my personal Mac mini, where I used to keep my laptop when it was connected to this monitor. So I naturally just hauled the cursor beyond the side of the screen, and it *magically* kept going onto the laptop screen! It took me several seconds to figure out that something special had happened and that my cursor had jumped from one machine to the other. Something weird: how did it know which side of my monitor the laptop was on? It could guess by choosing the direction you try to move your cursor, exactly like I did, but it's still absolutely delightful.

items.content_html:
Gave a bunch of stuff back to Apple today. These computers got both Meera and me through college and grad school, and it‚Äôs time to let go.

The white iPod (3rd gen, I think) was a birthday present when I turned 17 or 18; the iPods Touch tided me over until Verizon got the iPhone, and that iPhone 5s is still the best design ever made.

items.content_html:
Today I discovered Merlin Mann’s Wisdom Project, and it’s the kind of thing at least part of my Micro.blog should aspire to be.

Little snippets that are helpful to me now and might be helpful to me or others later.

Some of them are very #wisdom:

Like it or not, you’re always practicing something. Put another way, whichever muscle you exercise the most can’t help but strengthen. Often to the detriment of others.

And some are pure Merlin:

Your calendar represents a portfolio of promises to your future self. Treat it that way.
items.content_text:
Today I discovered Merlin Mann's [Wisdom Project](https://github.com/merlinmann/wisdom), and it's the kind of thing at least part of my Micro.blog should aspire to be.

Little snippets that are helpful to me now and might be helpful to me or others later.

Some of them are very #wisdom:

> Like it or not, you're always practicing something. Put another way, whichever muscle you exercise the most can't help but strengthen. Often to the detriment of others.

And some are pure Merlin:

> Your calendar represents a portfolio of promises to your future self. Treat it that way.

items.content_html:
Cleaning out and backing up my college/grad school MacBook Pro (15-inch Early 2008), and the nostalgia is strong in this one.

Sure, its 2.4GHz Core 2 Duo isn‚Äôt that impressive, and neither is its 4GB of DDR2 or 256GB GeForce 8600M, but it is weirdly performant on OS X 10.8.3, and the aesthetic is arguably more beautiful and indisputably more fun than current macOS.

The old-school 3D icons for Twitter, TextWrangler, and others are elegant, and maybe we should go back to them.

I did all of grad school on this computer, including tons of Matlab and hundreds of pages of LaTeX, and it‚Äôs kind of sad to see it go.
items.content_text:

The old-school 3D icons for Twitter, TextWrangler, and others are elegant, and maybe we should go back to them.

I did all of grad school on this computer, including tons of Matlab and hundreds of pages of LaTeX, and it‚Äôs kind of sad to see it go.

items.content_html: Finished reading: Moving Pictures by Terry Pratchett. Like ‚ÄúPyramids‚Äù, an excuse for Pratchett to make a billion pop culture jokes in a row. Tons of fun. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Moving Pictures](https://micro.blog/books/9781407034737) by Terry Pratchett. Like ‚ÄúPyramids‚Äù, an excuse for Pratchett to make a billion pop culture jokes in a row. Tons of fun. üìö

items.content_html: Finished watching: Hidden Figures. I‚Äôm so glad this movie exists. Epic women I‚Äôve looked up to forever, especially Katherine Johnson, and now other people will know about them too. Not a movie for nerds‚Äîit‚Äôs about people and society and space, not technology‚Äîbut awesome anyway.üçø

items.content_html: Finished reading: Spinning Silver by Naomi Novik. Wow, what a fun novel. I had no idea what was going on or what was going to happen. Definitely better than her Uprooted. Thanks to @jsonbecker for saying exactly that and giving me the recommendation. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Spinning Silver](https://micro.blog/books/9780399181009) by Naomi Novik. Wow, what a fun novel. I had no idea what was going on or what was going to happen. Definitely better than her _Uprooted_. Thanks to [@jsonbecker](https://micro.blog/jsonbecker) for saying exactly that and giving me the recommendation. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: The Wise Man’s Fear by Patrick Rothfuss. I‚Äôve never read a book so full of hints but so devoid of answers. Also with such a powerful, but dumb, protagonist. I want Denna‚Äôs story so badly‚Ä¶ which I guess puts me in good company. A book practically made for Reddit. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [The Wise Man's Fear](https://micro.blog/books/9780575099562) by Patrick Rothfuss. I‚Äôve never read a book so full of hints but so devoid of answers. items.content_html: Finished reading: The Name of the Wind by Patrick Rothfuss. Late to the party on this one. One of the most beautiful fantasy books I‚Äôve ever read. Incredible command of language and myth and character. Also frustrating; I knew that going in, but I didn‚Äôt know just quite how. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [The Name of the Wind](https://micro.blog/books/9780756405892) by Patrick Rothfuss. Late to the party on this one. One of the most beautiful fantasy books I‚Äôve ever read. Incredible command of language and myth and character. Also frustrating; I knew that going in, but I didn‚Äôt know just quite how. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Eric by Terry Pratchett. Just fun. Less effort than previous books, but more entertaining. Plus: Rincewind! Only problem is it‚Äôs very very short. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Eric](https://micro.blog/books/9780575123151) by Terry Pratchett. Just fun. Less effort than previous books, but more entertaining. Plus: Rincewind! Only problem is it‚Äôs very very short. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: League of Dragons by Naomi Novik. Probably my favorite of these, which is nice because it‚Äôs last. Pacing worked out, some growth arcs concluded, and the inevitable future is hinted but not written. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [League of Dragons](https://micro.blog/books/9780345522924) by Naomi Novik. Probably my favorite of these, which is nice because it‚Äôs last. Pacing worked out, some growth arcs concluded, and the inevitable future is hinted but not written. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Blood of Tyrants by Naomi Novik. I will never get used to the pacing of these books; and especially the ridiculously abrupt endings. Not even cliffhangers, just endings. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Blood of Tyrants](https://micro.blog/books/9780593359617) by Naomi Novik. I will never get used to the pacing of these books; and especially the ridiculously abrupt endings. Not even cliffhangers, just endings. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Crucible of Gold by Naomi Novik. Fantastic adventure in the Andes devolves to more boring British politics by the end. Novik loves the history of the Napoleonic wars too much, and it weakens the stories. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Crucible of Gold](https://micro.blog/books/9780345522870) by Naomi Novik. Fantastic adventure in the Andes devolves to more boring British politics by the end. Novik loves the history of the Napoleonic wars too much, and it weakens the stories. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Tongues of Serpents by Naomi Novik. Unexpectedly appropriate for my long layover in Sydney. I like Laurence better as an explorer than soldier. More adventure, less British politics. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Tongues of Serpents](https://micro.blog/books/9780345521750) by Naomi Novik. Unexpectedly appropriate for my long layover in Sydney. I like Laurence better as an explorer than soldier. More adventure, less British politics. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Victory of Eagles by Naomi Novik. Pacing finally feels good, and as a result I enjoyed this one more than the previous four. Feels like the world is changing, which is fun to watch. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Victory of Eagles](https://micro.blog/books/9780345507082) by Naomi Novik. Pacing finally feels good, and as a result I enjoyed this one more than the previous four. Feels like the world is changing, which is fun to watch. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Tress of the Emerald Sea by Brandon Sanderson. Tremendous effort and tons of fun. Lots of Cosmere elements together, and the joy of Hoid everywhere. I just wish he hadn‚Äôt tried so hard to sound like Terry Pratchett. (Recommended by @manton) üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Tress of the Emerald Sea](https://micro.blog/books/9781938570346) by Brandon Sanderson. Tremendous effort and tons of fun. Lots of Cosmere elements together, and the joy of Hoid everywhere. I just wish he hadn‚Äôt tried so hard to sound like Terry Pratchett. (Recommended by [@manton](https://micro.blog/manton)) üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Guards! Guards! by Terry Pratchett. Probably my least favorite of the series so far. So many moving parts, and the jokes didn‚Äôt land for me. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Guards! Guards!](https://micro.blog/books/9781473200180) by Terry Pratchett. Probably my least favorite of the series so far. So many moving parts, and the jokes didn‚Äôt land for me. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: The Lost Metal by Brandon Sanderson. I absolutely tore through this book. As usual, Sanderson‚Äôs organization awes me, although I couldn‚Äôt help but feel he tossed a little too much Cosmere lore at us in one book to prepare us for what‚Äôs coming. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [The Lost Metal](https://micro.blog/books/9781473215290) by Brandon Sanderson. I absolutely tore through this book. As usual, Sanderson‚Äôs organization awes me, although I couldn‚Äôt help but feel he tossed a little too much Cosmere lore at us in one book to prepare us for what‚Äôs coming. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Empire of Ivory by Naomi Novik. More like a log of adventure than a novel. Temeraire and Laurence finally have a hard decision to make, although their expressed value system removes the tension entirely for the reader. Still a fun adventure though. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Empire of Ivory](https://micro.blog/books/9780593359570) by Naomi Novik. More like a log of adventure than a novel. Temeraire and Laurence finally have a hard decision to make, although their expressed value system removes the tension entirely for the reader. Still a fun adventure though. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Throne of Jade by Naomi Novik. Seemingly totally independent from the first novel except the characters, another exploration into a world where dragons are rare but natural. The pacing is again weird, but the world entertaining enough to make up for it. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Throne of Jade](https://micro.blog/books/9780593359556) by Naomi Novik. Seemingly totally independent from the first novel except the characters, another exploration into a world where dragons are rare but natural. The pacing is again weird, but the world entertaining enough to make up for it. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: His Majesty’s Dragon by Naomi Novik. Learning a new world is always fun, and Novik launches in as if England and France have always used dragon fleets in their wars. The climax is too long in coming though, and too short; similarly, the denouement is precipitous. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [His Majesty's Dragon](https://micro.blog/books/9780593359549) by Naomi Novik. Learning a new world is always fun, and Novik launches in as if England and France have always used dragon fleets in their wars. The climax is too long in coming though, and too short; similarly, the denouement is precipitous. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Pyramids by Terry Pratchett. Long train rides make these books fly by. Another one, like Wyrd Sisters, where Pratchett clearly enjoyed himself with puns and satire and camels. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Pyramids](https://micro.blog/books/9780061020650) by Terry Pratchett. Long train rides make these books fly by. Another one, like Wyrd Sisters, where Pratchett clearly enjoyed himself with puns and satire and camels. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Wyrd Sisters by Terry Pratchett. The first Discworld novel that actually made me laugh out loud. The Discworld is the same glorious place, but the words‚Äîpowerful things‚Äîtickled me just right. I suspect I missed a lot more literature references than I got. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Wyrd Sisters](https://micro.blog/books/9780062225733) by Terry Pratchett. The first Discworld novel that actually made me laugh out loud. The Discworld is the same glorious place, but the words‚Äîpowerful things‚Äîtickled me just right. I suspect I missed a lot more literature references than I got. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: The Bear and the Nightingale by Katherine Arden. Takes a long time to get going, but spellbinding once there. Another winter fairy tale. Recommended by @hollyhoneychurch as a follow-up to Uprooted; good recommendation. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [The Bear and the Nightingale](https://micro.blog/books/9781101885949) by Katherine Arden. Takes a long time to get going, but spellbinding once there. Another winter fairy tale. Recommended by [@hollyhoneychurch](https://micro.blog/hollyhoneychurch) as a follow-up to Uprooted; good recommendation. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Sourcery by Terry Pratchett. The self-consistency of Discworld, despite the total lack of logic, amazes me every time. All of its legends and myths and prophecies are true, just never in ways the reader expects, yet somehow always in ways that blend comfortably with the overall chaos. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Sourcery](https://micro.blog/books/9780613572781) by Terry Pratchett. The self-consistency of Discworld, despite the total lack of logic, amazes me every time. All of its legends and myths and prophecies are true, just never in ways the reader expects, yet somehow always in ways that blend comfortably with the overall chaos. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Mort by Terry Pratchett. Death hires an apprentice so he can take some time off and experience life, and maybe find a husband for his daughter. All of those things happen, but as is common on Discworld, not exactly in the expected fashion. Rincewind cameo. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Mort](https://micro.blog/books/9780552166621) by Terry Pratchett. Death hires an apprentice so he can take some time off and experience life, and maybe find a husband for his daughter. All of those things happen, but as is common on Discworld, not exactly in the expected fashion. Rincewind cameo. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Uprooted by Naomi Novik. Starts as a twist on a fairy tale, ends as high fantasy. The finale is a bit more chaotic than you‚Äôd wish, but the whole thing is a good time. 95% for children, but very much meant for grown-ups. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [Uprooted](https://micro.blog/books/9780804179041) by Naomi Novik. Starts as a twist on a fairy tale, ends as high fantasy. The finale is a bit more chaotic than you‚Äôd wish, but the whole thing is a good time. 95% for children, but very much meant for grown-ups. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: The Golden Enclaves by Naomi Novik. I absolutely devoured this book. It pays off the first book‚Äôs cliffhanger better than the second even tried to, and while the writing got a little cheaper the story exploded into awesome. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [The Golden Enclaves](https://micro.blog/books/9780593158364) by Naomi Novik. I absolutely devoured this book. It pays off the first book‚Äôs cliffhanger better than the second even tried to, and while the writing got a little cheaper the story exploded into awesome. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: The Last Graduate by Naomi Novik. More fun in the Scholomance. Cliffhanger from the previous novel doesn‚Äôt pay off, but a great read anyway. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [The Last Graduate](https://micro.blog/books/9780593128879) by Naomi Novik. More fun in the Scholomance. Cliffhanger from the previous novel doesn‚Äôt pay off, but a great read anyway. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: A Deadly Education by Naomi Novik. Clearly written for the Harry Potter set, but profoundly different and exciting and, helpfully, well-written. Immediately a favorite young adult novel. üìö
items.content_text: Finished reading: [A Deadly Education](https://micro.blog/books/9780593128497) by Naomi Novik. Clearly written for the Harry Potter set, but profoundly different and exciting and, helpfully, well-written. Immediately a favorite young adult novel. üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: The Bands of Mourning by Brandon Sanderson. Concludes as expected, a surprisingly similar scene to Hero of Ages. I wish we‚Äôd seen Hoid more, but the tease of Kelsier at the end was worth it.üìö

items.content_html: Finished reading: Shadows of Self by Brandon Sanderson. Beautiful, tragic, ending. Harsh cliffhanger, but didn‚Äôt leave me desperate for more Cosmere like most of this series does. üìö
